welcome.text: This simple walkthrough will explain the consent of research study. After you learn about the test, you can choose if you would like to participate.

dataGather.text: We will collect anonymous data from this screening test & study.

privacy.text: We will protect your privacy to the best of our ability. The coded data will be encrypted and stored on a secure cloud server (hipaa compliant) to prevent improper access.

dataUse.text: Your coded data will be used for research and may be shared with other researchers worldwide.

studySurvey.text: We will also ask you to answer brief surveys to understand some aspects and gather data.

potentialBenefits.text: You will be able to assess risk for ASD. The M-CHAT is validated for screening toddlers between 16 and 30 months of age, to assess risk for autism spectrum disorders (ASD)

potentialRisks.text: The primary goal of the M-CHAT was to maximize sensitivity, meaning to detect as many cases of ASD as possible. Therefore, there is a high false positive rate, meaning that not all children who score at risk for ASD will be diagnosed with ASD.

notMedicalCare.text: This test only for assess risk for autism spectrum disorders (ASD). There is a high false positive rate, meaning that not all children who score at risk for ASD will be diagnosed with ASD. Please advise your doctor for real medical answers.

followUp.text: We might want to reach you. You can opt out the follow up anytime.

stepQuestion1: Does your child enjoy being swung, bounced on your knee, etc.?
stepQuestion2: Does your child take an interest in other children?
stepQuestion3: Does your child like climbing on things, such as up stairs?
stepQuestion4: Does your child enjoy playing peek-a-boo/hide-and-seek?
stepQuestion5: Does your child ever pretend, for example, to talk on the phone or take care of a doll or pretend other things?
stepQuestion6: Does your child ever use his/her index finger to point, to ask for something?
stepQuestion7: Does your child ever use his/her index finger to point, to indicate interest in something?
stepQuestion8: Can your child play properly with small toys (e.g. cars or blocks) without just mouthing, fiddling, or dropping them?
stepQuestion9: Does your child ever bring objects over to you (parent) to show you something?
stepQuestion10: Does your child look you in the eye for more than a second or two?
stepQuestion11: Does your child ever seem oversensitive to noise? (e.g., plugging ears)
stepQuestion12: Does your child smile in response to your face or your smile?
stepQuestion13: Does your child imitate you? (e.g., you make a face-will your child imitate it?)
stepQuestion14: Does your child respond to his/her name when you call?
stepQuestion15: If you point at a toy across the room, does your child look at it?
stepQuestion17: Does your child look at things you are looking at?
stepQuestion18: Does your child make unusual finger movements near his/her face?
stepQuestion19: Does your child try to attract your attention to his/her own activity?
stepQuestion20: Have you ever wondered if your child is deaf?
stepQuestion21: Does your child understand what people say?
stepQuestion22: Does your child sometimes stare at nothing or wander with no purpose?
stepQuestion23: Does your child look at your face to check your reaction when faced with something unfamiliar?
